pull.title: Improved readability of ApproximateBestSubset
pull.body:
[`vValue` is sorted](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L1704) into [ascending order](http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/sort/) before [ApproximateBestSubset(...)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L1591) is called. 

Currently, after a new best set is found, the final element that was added [gets removed from the set](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L1629), and the [inner loop](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L1608) continues to search through the remainder of `vValue` for a better set. It is however impossible for a better set to be achieved with a later element in `vValue`: As `vValue` is sorted in ascending order, any set formed with a later element will be of same size or bigger.

Therefore, the lines [1628](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L1628) & [1629](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L1629) are obsolete, and the inner loop should also stop on `fReachedTarget`.

rename.from: Removed obsolete lines of code, broke continuation of loop.
rename.to: ApproximateBestSubset: Removed obsolete lines of code, broke continuation of loop

events.body: vValue is not sorted in ascending order, the whole algorithm wouldn't make sense if it was...

> If you say this sorts it in descending order, I don't see where that happens.

Right in the line where `std::sort()` is called: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/5dc63ed1ca8aca62f28881ba9ef996d4036a23ea/src/wallet/wallet.cpp#L1719

`r` means reverse and the reverse of ascending is descending?

> links always refer to the current version and shift around because of that

@Xekyo If you want to link on GitHub, don't forget to press the `y`-Key before copy pasting the link
Yikes, that's easy to overlook, perhaps a comment.
And a unit test because this PR should not pass travis in the first place.
@Xekyo Can you take a look at this and add a comment above the "`sort()`-line"?

> Yikes, that's easy to overlook, perhaps a comment.

Absolutely. I also had no idea that you could pass reverse iterators to std::sort and it would just work.
Sounds ok to me. Are you planning to write the unit test as well?

@MarcoFalke: I could do that, yet I’m unsure what one would want to test. Since the sorting operation is in the middle of  `CWallet::SelectCoinsMinConf(…)`, it’s would require quite a bit of refactoring to isolate as `vValue` is only a transient variable in that function.
@Xekyo I mean a "high level" test like #7193, such that your initial commit will fail travis. (Would you mind to post the inital diff or commit hash for reference and testing, I forgot to save it.)

@MarcoFalke: Unfortunately, I also overwrote my commit when I rebased my branch (perhaps prematurely) and pushed it to my fork. Would it make sense to redo them and push them onto another branch?

I’ve added a test.

rename.from: ApproximateBestSubset: Removed obsolete lines of code, broke continuation of loop

rename.to: Improved readability of ApproximateBestSubset, added test to check for suboptimal result of selection.

rename.from: Improved readability of ApproximateBestSubset, added test to check for suboptimal result of selection.

Nit: you could use `std::sort` and `std:reverse` to prevent follow up commits.

events.message:
Improved readability of sorting for coin selection.

Future proofing added lines

events.body: Edited to include the nit. :)
trivial re-ACK 96efcad
utACK 96efcadfc0d8a84066982533c676072d3b5d8314
utACK 96efcad
Is there some reason not to just invert the CompareValueOnly function?
And call it ReverseCompareValueOnly, yes that would have been the other option. But let's leave it as it is now, there's no need to shedpaint this.

comments.body: This will select quite a bunch of the 3ct coins, I don't think you want this. Just reduce the number to `1` like #7293
@Xekyo You can either get the test case from #7293 and include it here or remove the test case in this pull.
I’ve ACKed #7293 and will remove the test case here.
